outputValidation.content:
{
  "problem_id": "P02",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 1.85,
    "units": "g",
    "precision_note": "Mass inputs are 3 s.f., so report CO2 mass to 3 s.f."
  },
  "method": "Mass of pure calcium carbonate in the limestone is 84.0% of 5.00 g: m(CaCO3) = 5.00×0.840 = 4.20 g. Use n = m/Mr. From the given atomic/formula data, Mr(CaCO3) = 40.1 + 12.0 + 3×16.0 = 100.1, so n(CaCO3) = 4.20/100.1 = 0.04196 mol. The reaction CaCO3 + 2HCl → CaCl2 + CO2 + H2O shows a 1:1 mol ratio CaCO3:CO2, so n(CO2) = 0.04196 mol. Mr(CO2) = 12.0 + 2×16.0 = 44.0, so mass of CO2 is m = nMr = 0.04196×44.0 = 1.85 g (3 s.f.).",
  "key_equations": [
    "n = m / Mr",
    "CaCO3 : CO2 = 1 : 1",
    "m = nMr"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L14",
    "L24",
    "L33",
    "L34"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "Only 4.20 g of CaCO3 can react; getting ~1.85 g CO2 is plausible because CO2 has lower Mr than CaCO3.",
    "Acid is in excess, so CaCO3 amount is the limiting factor as assumed."
  ]
}

{
  "problem_id": "P05",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 0.89,
    "units": "g",
    "precision_note": "Limited by I (1.50 A) and time (30.0 min), so report mass to 3 s.f."
  },
  "method": "Current is 1.50 A for 30.0 min, so time in seconds is t = 30.0×60 = 1800 s and charge passed is Q = I×t = 1.50×1800 = 2700 C. Faraday constant F = 96,500 C mol-1 means 96,500 C corresponds to 1 mol of electrons, so n(e−) = 2700/96500 = 0.02798 mol e−. From the half-equation Cu2+ + 2e− → Cu, 2 mol e− deposit 1 mol Cu, so n(Cu) = 0.02798/2 = 0.01399 mol. Using the given atomic mass of copper (63.55 g mol-1), m(Cu) = 0.01399×63.55 = 0.890 g, which rounds to 0.890 g (3 s.f.).",
  "key_equations": [
    "Q = I * t",
    "n(e-) = Q / F",
    "Cu2+ + 2e- -> Cu",
    "m = nMr"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L19",
    "L24",
    "L51",
    "L52"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "Charge scales with current and time (Q = It), so doubling either would double the deposited mass.",
    "Because 2 e− are needed per Cu, the amount of Cu must be half the amount of electrons."
  ]
}

critical_issues: P01: The computed concentration is correctly shown as 0.0200 mol dm-3 in the method, but the numeric JSON value is given as 0.02. Because JSON numbers cannot preserve trailing zeros, the stated precision is only carried in the precision_note; downstream consumers must respect that note to avoid interpreting the answer as 2 s.f.
value.summary: All six outputs are consistent with the provided report data and equations, with no fabricated quantities or unsupported assumptions. Each solution uses only the listed constants/formulae (e.g., dilution c1V1=c2V2 at L16; stoichiometry with given Mr values at L24–L26; titration via c=n/V at L15 and equation at L40; bond energy method at L47 with energies at L46; electrolysis using Q=It and F=96,500 at L17–L19; equilibrium Kc expression at L20 with conversion to concentration using vessel volume,
